content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Leticia Daniels: I was born and raised in Charlotte, North Carolina, in a tight-knit neighborhood where everyone knew each other. My parents were both hardworking, and though they didn't have a lot of money, they always made sure my brother and I had everything we needed. My father was a teacher with a bachelor's degree, and my mother had an associate's degree but chose to stay home for a while when I was young. I grew up in a Christian household, though I haven't been religious for quite some time now. I always had a good education, and I was the first in my family to go to college. I studied business, which I thought would be a stable path, but after graduation, I found myself taking a different route. I got married young, but the marriage didn't last, and I ended up raising my son alone. I've been a full-time homemaker for the past few years, but I still keep my mind sharp by reading and learning new things. Life hasn't always gone the way I expected, but I've learned to adapt and find joy in the little things.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Leticia Daniels: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads. After I graduated with my bachelor's in business, I had a job offer from a local company, but I also met someone and got pregnant shortly after. I was young and scared, and I chose to put my career on hold to raise my son. Looking back, I think I was trying to prove something to myself—that I could be a good mother and still have a stable life. But over time, I realized that I missed the challenge of work, the sense of purpose it gave me. I tried going back to school a few years later, but it was hard to balance everything. Eventually, I decided to focus on being a homemaker and raising my son the best I could. I don't regret my choices, but I do wonder what my life would have been like if I had taken that job and pursued my career first. It's funny how life has a way of redirecting you, sometimes in ways you don't expect.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Leticia Daniels: I think it was a mix of both, honestly. I made the choice to step away from my career, but life had a way of making it feel like it 'just happened' at times. I was so focused on being there for my son, on giving him the love and stability I thought he needed, that I didn't always see the other paths clearly. I remember sitting at my desk one day, looking at the job offer in front of me, and realizing I was more scared of failing as a mother than I was of failing in my career. It wasn't a single moment, but a series of small decisions that added up. I don't think I would have made the same choice if I were older or more confident in myself. But I also know that I made the best decision I could with the information and emotions I had at the time. Life has a way of teaching you lessons, even when you don't see them coming.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Leticia Daniels: Absolutely, I think having someone to talk to or even just a few resources could have made a difference. At the time, I didn't really know where to turn. I was young, and I didn't have a strong support network outside of my family. My parents were supportive, but they had their own lives and challenges. I wish I had reached out to a counselor or a mentor who could have helped me navigate those decisions with more clarity. There were organizations in the community that offered support for young mothers, but I didn't know about them. Looking back, I think if I had access to more information or guidance, I might have felt more confident in making a choice that balanced both my career and my role as a mother. It's something I've come to appreciate more now, especially as my son gets older and I see how important it is to have support systems in place.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Leticia Daniels: Right now, my son is my main focus. He's 12 years old, and he's a bright, curious kid with a passion for science. We live in the same house I grew up in, and it feels like home. I don't have a partner at the moment, but I've never been one to rush into relationships. I want to make sure I'm emotionally and mentally ready to give someone else the kind of love and attention my son deserves. My parents are still around, and though they live a few towns over, we stay in touch regularly. My mother, in particular, has been a big support to me over the years. She's the one who encouraged me to go back to school a few years ago, even though I didn't end up finishing. I also have a few close friends from high school who I still keep in touch with—though life has taken us in different directions, we always make time for each other. Family and friends are the foundation of my life, and I'm grateful for them every day.

Going through the interview questions reminded me of how much my life has evolved over the years. Starting from my childhood in Charlotte, to making the tough decision to step away from my career after college, to raising my son alone and finding my own sense of purpose as a homemaker, each part of my journey has shaped who I am today. It was also interesting to reflect on the crossroads I faced and how, at the time, I thought I was making the best choice for my son and myself. Looking back, I realize how much support I could have used, and how much I've grown from the experiences I had. Now, with my son growing up and my own life continuing to unfold, I feel more confident in who I am and the path I've chosen. It's not the path I originally imagined, but it's mine, and I'm grateful for every lesson it's taught me.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Leticia Daniels: My brother, Marcus, is someone I haven't mentioned yet. He's a few years older than me, and we've always had a strong bond. He's a nurse in a nearby hospital, and he's been my rock through a lot of the challenges I've faced over the years. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but whenever we do, it's like no time has passed. He's the one who helped me get back on my feet after my divorce, even lending me money when I needed it most. We have our differences, of course—like most siblings—but I know I can always count on him. He's the kind of person who puts others first, and I admire that about him. I also have a cousin, Tiffany, who's like a sister to me. She's a teacher in the same school district as my son, and she's been a great influence on him. She's helped me feel more connected to the community and has even offered to help me with some of the things I've been thinking about—like maybe going back to school again someday. Family, in all its forms, has been such an important part of my life, and I'm grateful for each of them in their own way.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Leticia Daniels: Yes, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. We were roommates, and even though we went different ways after graduation, we've stayed close. She's a social worker now, and she's always been the one to remind me that it's okay to ask for help. She's the kind of person who listens without judgment and has been there for me through some really tough times. Then there's Jamal, who I met through a community center program when I was trying to get back on my feet after my divorce. He's a graphic designer, and he's helped me with some of the creative projects I've taken on in my free time—like designing a small online store for handmade crafts I started making. He's also the one who introduced me to a local support group for single mothers, which has been a huge help. These people, even though they're not family, have been like family to me. They've helped me feel less alone and reminded me that I'm not the only one navigating life's challenges.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Leticia Daniels: I live in a quiet neighborhood on Magnolia Lane, just a few blocks from where I grew up. It's a mix of older homes and newer developments, and there's a real sense of community here. The street is lined with oak trees, and in the spring, the blossoms are beautiful. Most of my neighbors are families with kids, which makes it feel like a safe and welcoming place for my son. There's a small park nearby where he plays with other kids, and I often see the same faces there—parents chatting while their children run around. I've been here for almost a decade now, and it's become my home in every sense of the word. I love the pace of life here—it's not too fast, not too slow. It gives me time to reflect, to be present with my son, and to enjoy the little things like the smell of fresh-baked bread from the bakery down the street or the sound of birds in the morning. It's a place that feels like it's been waiting for me, even if I didn't realize it at the time.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Leticia Daniels: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a real sense of community, and people look out for each other. I've never had any issues with crime or anything like that. The park is always busy with kids and parents, and I've never felt uncomfortable leaving my son to play while I run errands. I think it's the kind of place where if you're a neighbor, you know each other's names, and that makes a big difference. It's not perfect, of course—there are always challenges in any community—but overall, I feel secure and at peace in my neighborhood. It's one of the reasons I've stayed here all these years, even though I know life could have taken me elsewhere.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Leticia Daniels: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. One of the biggest ups is the sense of familiarity—it feels like coming home every time I walk through the front door. I know the neighbors, I know the rhythm of the street, and I know that my son is growing up in a place that feels safe and nurturing. But there are downs too. Sometimes, I feel like I'm stuck in a routine, and it's hard to break out of it. I used to dream of traveling or taking on new challenges, but with my son's needs and the responsibilities of being a homemaker, it's not always easy to pursue those dreams. Still, I try to find little ways to keep my life interesting—whether it's taking a walk through the park, baking something new, or even just having a deep conversation with a friend. I think the key is finding balance. This neighborhood has given me that balance, and for that, I'm grateful.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and places around me. Talking about my son, my parents, my brother, and my friends reminded me of how important it is to have a strong support system, especially when life takes unexpected turns. It also made me appreciate how much my neighborhood has been a constant in my life—providing a sense of safety, community, and familiarity. I realized that even though I didn't follow the path I originally imagined, I've found a kind of peace and stability in the life I've built here, surrounded by the people I love.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Leticia Daniels: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, though I do try to mix things up a bit to keep things from feeling too repetitive. Most mornings start with my son getting up, and we have a routine—breakfast, a quick walk around the block, and then he heads off to school. I usually spend the morning catching up on things around the house—cooking, cleaning, maybe doing some laundry or organizing. I also try to set aside some time for myself, whether it's reading a book, working on a craft project, or just sitting in the backyard with a cup of coffee and watching the birds. Afternoons are usually quieter, and I often use that time to catch up on emails or phone calls with friends and family. On weekends, we like to go to the park, visit the library, or maybe have a picnic in the backyard. I also try to make time for some light exercise, like yoga or a walk, to keep myself grounded. It's not always perfect, but I find comfort in the rhythm of it all. It's a life that's not about excitement or adventure, but about presence, and I've come to appreciate that more than I ever thought I would.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Leticia Daniels: Right now, I'm not working in a traditional job, but I do have a few side projects that keep me engaged. I started a small online store a few years back where I sell handmade crafts—mostly candles, soaps, and bath bombs. It's something I do in my free time, and it's been a nice way to stay creative and earn a little extra income. I usually work on it in the afternoons or evenings when my son is occupied with homework or activities. I also volunteer at the community center a couple of times a month, helping with after-school programs for kids. It's not a full-time job, but it gives me a sense of purpose and keeps me connected to the neighborhood. I've thought about going back to school for something like business or education, but I'm still figuring out how to balance that with everything else. For now, I'm content with what I have, even if it's not the path I originally imagined.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Leticia Daniels: One of the other routines I have is helping my son with his homework a few times a week, especially with his science projects. He's really into it, and I try to encourage his curiosity by doing experiments with him or looking up interesting facts together. I also make it a point to attend most of his school events, like parent-teacher conferences and science fairs. It's important to me that I'm involved in his education, even if I'm not in a traditional career. On top of that, I have a weekly routine of going to the grocery store, planning meals for the week, and making sure we have everything we need. I also take care of my parents' garden sometimes when they're away, which is a nice way to stay connected to them and keep my hands busy. And of course, I have my evening routine—reading a chapter of a book, journaling, and talking to my friends or family. These little things add up, and they help me feel grounded and connected to the world around me.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Leticia Daniels: One of the recent changes to my daily routine has been taking up gardening more seriously. I've always had a green thumb, but with my son's growing interest in science, I thought it would be a great way to combine our passions. We've started a small garden in the backyard where we grow herbs, tomatoes, and some flowers. It's become a little project we work on together, and it's amazing how much he's learned about plants, soil, and the cycle of life. I've also started sharing some of the produce with neighbors, which has been a nice way to connect with people and give back to the community. It's a small change, but it's added a new kind of joy to my days—one that feels both purposeful and peaceful.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Leticia Daniels: My son's typical weekday during the school year starts early—usually around 7 a.m., when he gets up and we have a quick breakfast together. He's in sixth grade now, and his school day runs from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. After school, he usually has a snack and then heads to his after-school activities. He's in a robotics club twice a week, which he absolutely loves. It's at the community center, and he's been working on building a small robot with some of his friends. On the other days, he either goes to the library or does homework with me. I try to make sure he has time to unwind, so we often have a family dinner together, and then he'll either watch a show or read a book before bed. I've also started helping him with his science fair projects, which has been a lot of fun. He's really passionate about it, and I love seeing his excitement when he discovers something new. It's amazing how much he's grown, both academically and personally, and I feel so lucky to be part of his journey.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and places around me. Talking about my son, my parents, my brother, and my friends reminded me of how important it is to have a strong support system, especially when life takes unexpected turns. It also made me appreciate how much my neighborhood has been a constant in my life—providing a sense of safety, community, and familiarity. I realized that even though I didn't follow the path I originally imagined, I've found a kind of peace and stability in the life I've built here, surrounded by the people I love.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Leticia Daniels: My health has been pretty good overall, though I've had my share of ups and downs. I used to be pretty active, but after my son was born, I found it harder to keep up with the same routine. I still try to stay as healthy as I can—eating well, getting enough sleep, and making time for exercise, even if it's just a short walk or some yoga in the morning. I do have some chronic issues with my back, probably from years of sitting at a desk during my college days and then lifting things around the house as a homemaker. I see a chiropractor every few months, and I take some over-the-counter pain relievers when needed. I also try to stay on top of my mental health, which has been a learning process for me. There were times when I felt overwhelmed or isolated, especially in the early years of raising my son alone, but I've learned to prioritize self-care now. I've started journaling more, and I've even joined a local meditation group that meets once a week. It's helped me feel more centered and grounded. I think the key is not waiting until something is wrong to take care of yourself—it's about being proactive and listening to your body and mind.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Leticia Daniels: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine that I can rely on—like my morning walks, my evening meditation, and the little things like cooking meals from scratch instead of relying on takeout. It's also the support from my son and friends who remind me to take breaks and not push myself too hard. What makes it hard, though, is the constant juggling act. There are days when I feel like I'm stretched thin, and I forget to prioritize my own needs. I used to think that taking care of myself was selfish, but I've learned that it's not—it's necessary. When I'm healthy, I'm better able to be there for my son, to enjoy the little moments, and to feel like myself again. It's a work in progress, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself along the way.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Leticia Daniels: In the past two years, I've had a few flare-ups with my back pain, especially after lifting something heavy while helping my son with a science project. It reminded me how important it is to be careful with my body, especially since I'm not as young as I used to be. I also had a minor case of pneumonia last winter, which was a bit of a wake-up call. I hadn't been getting enough rest, and I think that contributed to it. It was tough being sick while also taking care of my son, but it taught me to listen to my body more closely. Since then, I've been more consistent with my chiropractic visits and even started seeing a physical therapist to strengthen my core. I've also been more mindful about pacing myself and not pushing through pain. It's not perfect, but I'm learning that taking care of my health is just as important as taking care of my son.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Leticia Daniels: Honestly, there were times when my health issues made it harder to keep up with everything, especially when I was dealing with the back pain and that pneumonia episode. I remember one week when I was so exhausted from coughing and fever that I barely had the energy to get my son ready for school. It was a wake-up call for me—realizing that if I don't take care of myself, I can't take care of him the way I want to. I've had to learn to ask for help more, whether it's from my brother, my friends, or even just taking a day to rest when I need to. It's not always easy, but I've come to understand that my health is just as important as my son's. I can't be the best version of myself for him if I'm constantly running on empty. It's a balance I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be more intentional about it now.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Leticia Daniels: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—mostly gratitude, but also a sense of growth that I didn't expect. I've been trying to be more present in my son's life, and I think that's made a big difference for both of us. I've also been more open about my own feelings, which has helped me connect with people in a deeper way. There were moments when I felt overwhelmed, especially with the back pain and the pneumonia, but those challenges taught me to slow down and really listen to what my body and my heart are telling me. I've started journaling more consistently, and it's been a great way to process my thoughts and emotions. I also feel like I'm finally starting to see the value in taking time for myself, even if it's just a few minutes of quiet reflection each day. Life hasn't been perfect, but I feel more at peace with it than I ever have before.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes and health made me realize how much I've grown over the past few years. Starting a garden with my son has not only brought us closer but also given me a new sense of purpose and connection to the world around me. It's amazing how something as simple as planting herbs and tomatoes can bring so much joy and learning into our daily lives. At the same time, reflecting on my health reminded me of the importance of taking care of myself, not just for my own well-being but also for my son's. I used to think that prioritizing my health was selfish, but now I see it as essential. It's not about being perfect—it's about being present, listening to my body, and making small, intentional choices that support both my physical and mental health. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Leticia Daniels: I've had my moments of feeling really low, especially in the early years after my divorce and when I was raising my son alone. There were times when I felt like I was carrying the weight of the world on my shoulders, and I didn't know how to ask for help. I think I used to confuse sadness with weakness, and I didn't want anyone to see me as broken or incapable. But over the past few years, I've come to understand that it's okay to feel vulnerable, to feel anxious, or even to feel like I'm not enough. I've started talking more openly about these feelings with my friends, especially Sarah, who has been a huge support. I've also started seeing a therapist, which has been really helpful in learning how to manage my thoughts and emotions. I don't think I would have reached out before, but I've learned that asking for help isn't a sign of failure—it's a sign of strength. I still have days when I feel overwhelmed, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to recognize when I need to pause, breathe, and take care of my mental health. It's a journey, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Leticia Daniels: For my family, especially my son, the past year has been a mix of growth and challenges. He's becoming more independent, which is both exciting and a little bittersweet. I've been trying to let go of some of the control I used to have, and it's been hard at times. But I've also seen him develop a stronger sense of responsibility and curiosity, especially with his science projects and his interest in the garden we started together. My parents have been doing well too—they're both in their 60s now, and while they've had their own health issues, they're staying active and involved in the community. My brother has been a constant source of support, and I feel lucky to have him in my life. Overall, I think we've all been learning to be more patient with each other and with ourselves. It's not always easy, but I believe we're all growing in our own ways, and that gives me hope for the future.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Leticia Daniels: I used to be pretty religious, especially growing up in a Christian household. My parents were both active in church, and I remember going to Sunday school and feeling a real sense of community there. But over time, as I got older and started thinking more critically about the world, I found myself questioning a lot of the things I was taught. I wasn't necessarily angry or disillusioned, but I just didn't feel like the faith I was raised with fit the way I saw life anymore. Now, I don't identify with any particular religion, but I do think spirituality—whether it's in nature, in the connections we have with others, or in the quiet moments of reflection—plays an important role in my life. I find peace in the little things, like watching the sunrise or listening to my son laugh, and I think that's its own kind of faith. I don't need a label to feel connected to something bigger than myself.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Leticia Daniels: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I find that it can be a bit overwhelming with all the noise and comparison, and I prefer to keep my life more grounded in the real world. That said, I do have a Facebook account where I stay in touch with family and some old friends. I like seeing photos of my parents, my brother, and even some of my cousins who live out of state. I also follow a few pages that share gardening tips and science-related content, which aligns with my interests and what I do with my son. I think social media can be a good tool if used mindfully, but I've found that for me, it's easier to disconnect and focus on the people and things that matter most in my daily life.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Leticia Daniels: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support, but I can see how it might help others. For me, the support has always come from the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and even my neighbors. When I was going through some tough times after my divorce, it was my brother who helped me get back on my feet, and my friend Sarah who reminded me that it was okay to feel lost sometimes. I think social media can be a double-edged sword. It can connect you with people who understand what you're going through, but it can also make you feel more isolated if you're comparing your life to others'. I've always preferred face-to-face conversations or even a phone call when I need support. There's something about hearing someone's voice or seeing their face that makes it feel more real and comforting. That said, I can see how it might be useful for someone who doesn't have a strong support system in their immediate life. I just know that for me, the real connections have always been the ones that matter most.

Going through the interview questions about my health and recent challenges made me realize how much I've grown in understanding the importance of taking care of myself. I used to think that prioritizing my well-being was selfish, but now I see it as essential—not just for me, but for my son and the people I love. The past year has been filled with moments of struggle, like dealing with back pain and pneumonia, but those experiences have taught me to listen to my body and not push through when I need to rest. I've also come to terms with my mental health, learning that it's okay to feel overwhelmed and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. It's been a journey, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the lessons I've learned along the way.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Leticia Daniels: Over the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have actually decreased a bit, which is something I didn't expect. I think it's because I've started to embrace the pace of my life instead of fighting against it. I used to worry that I wasn't living up to some invisible standard of success or productivity, but now I see that my life has its own kind of richness. I've also developed some new coping strategies, like journaling more consistently and taking short walks in the morning to clear my mind. I've even started meditating a few times a week, which has helped me feel more centered, especially when things get overwhelming. I've also learned to set boundaries—whether it's saying no to extra responsibilities or carving out time for myself when I need it. It's not always easy, but I've come to understand that taking care of my emotional well-being is just as important as taking care of my physical health. I think the biggest shift has been in how I view challenges. Instead of seeing them as obstacles, I now see them as opportunities to grow, and that has made a world of difference for me.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Leticia Daniels: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to groceries, my son's school supplies, and the utilities. With him in sixth grade, the cost of books, lab materials, and field trips has added up. I also had to budget for the gardening supplies we've been using, like soil, seeds, and tools. I try to be careful with my spending, so I set aside a portion of the income from my online store for these things. I also have a small emergency fund that I built up over the years, which has been helpful when unexpected costs come up, like a new pair of shoes for my son or a replacement for a broken appliance. I don't make a lot, but I've learned to prioritize what's truly important—like his education, our health, and the little things that bring us joy. It's not always easy, but I've found that being intentional with money helps me feel more in control and less stressed about the future.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Leticia Daniels: Last month, our household spent around $2,200, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend about $1,800 to $2,500 each month, depending on the season and any unexpected expenses. The bulk of that goes to groceries, which is always a big one—especially with my son's school meals and snacks. Then there's the utilities, like electricity and internet, which I try to keep under control by being mindful of usage. I also set aside money for his school supplies and extracurricular activities, like the robotics club. The income from my online store helps cover some of these costs, but it's not enough to live on entirely. I also have a small emergency fund that I've been building over the years, which has been a lifesaver for things like car maintenance or unexpected medical bills. It's not a lot, but it's enough to keep us afloat and give us some peace of mind.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Leticia Daniels: We own our home. It's the same house I grew up in, and it's been in my family for generations. My parents bought it when I was a child, and after they passed away, it was left to me and my brother. We decided to split the inheritance, and I kept the house because it felt like the right choice for me and my son. It's a bit old, but it's been well-maintained, and I've made some updates over the years—like installing new windows and fixing the roof. Owning a home has given me a sense of stability, especially when life gets busy. It's not always easy managing the costs of upkeep, but I've learned to budget for it and take things one step at a time. There are days when I wish I had more space or a bigger yard, but I've come to appreciate what we have. It's a place with history, and I want my son to grow up here just like I did, surrounded by the same trees and neighbors who've been part of our lives for so long.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Leticia Daniels: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, just like the seasons. In the winter, our heating bill went up a bit, which was expected, but I was careful to keep the temperature at a reasonable level to save money. I also noticed that our electricity bill fluctuated depending on how much we used for the garden lights and the small electric heater I use in the mornings. During the school year, we had a few unexpected expenses, like replacing my son's laptop when it started acting up, and paying for some of his science fair materials. Then there were the holidays—Thanksgiving and Christmas brought a bit more spending, especially on gifts for family and friends. I also had to budget for a few car repairs, which I didn't expect. But overall, I've been pretty consistent with our monthly spending, and I've learned to plan ahead for the bigger expenses, like the heating bill or school-related costs. It's not always perfect, but I've come to appreciate the rhythm of it all and how it fits into the life we've built here.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and I have grown over the past year, especially in terms of our emotional well-being and how we support one another. It reminded me of the importance of being present for my son as he becomes more independent, and how my own journey with mental health has allowed me to be more patient and understanding with him. It also made me think about how I don't rely on social media for support, but instead on the real, meaningful connections I have with my family and friends. I've come to realize that the strength of my relationships is what truly helps me navigate life's challenges, and I'm grateful for the people who have been there for me, even when I didn't always know how to ask for help.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Leticia Daniels: I do have a savings account, though it's not a huge amount. I've been trying to build it up over the years, especially after realizing how important it is to have a financial cushion. I set aside a small portion of the income from my online store each month, and I also contribute to it when I get unexpected windfalls, like a bonus from a local craft fair or a gift card I receive. I know it's not much, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that there's something there for emergencies. I also have a separate jar where I keep cash for smaller, everyday expenses—like groceries or gas. It's a simple system, but it works for me. I used to think saving wasn't necessary because I didn't make a lot, but I've learned that even small amounts add up over time. It's about being intentional with what I earn and making sure I'm not living paycheck to paycheck. I want my son to grow up knowing that saving is a habit worth developing, and I try to model that for him as best as I can.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Leticia Daniels: For me, saving has mostly been about preparing for the unexpected. Last year, I focused on building up my emergency fund a bit more after dealing with some health issues and the costs that came with them. I also started saving for a small project I've been thinking about—maybe expanding my online store or even taking a class to improve my skills. It's not about buying a house or something big like that, but more about having a little something set aside for when life throws a curveball. I've learned that even small savings can make a difference, and I want my son to see that it's not about having a lot, but about being responsible with what you have. It's a lesson I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be better about it every day.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Leticia Daniels: My occupation, if I had to define it, is a combination of things—homemaker, small business owner, and community volunteer. While I didn't pursue a traditional career path after college, I've found purpose in the roles I've taken on. As a homemaker, my duties include managing the household, caring for my son, and ensuring that our home is a place of comfort and stability. I also run a small online store where I sell handmade soaps, candles, and bath bombs. It started as a way to stay creative and earn some extra income, but it's grown into something I'm really proud of. I spend a lot of time researching natural ingredients, experimenting with new scents and textures, and packaging everything with care. It's not a high-paying job, but it gives me a sense of accomplishment and allows me to connect with people who appreciate handmade products. On top of that, I volunteer at the community center a few times a month, helping with after-school programs for kids. It's rewarding to see the kids learn and grow, and it keeps me connected to the neighborhood. I don't think of myself as a traditional worker, but I believe that the work I do—whether it's in the home, in my small business, or in the community—matters just as much as any other kind of job. It's a different kind of work, but it's mine, and I'm learning to appreciate it more every day.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Leticia Daniels: I don't work in the traditional sense of having a 9-to-5 job, but if I had to break it down, I'd say I work around 20 to 25 hours a week on my online store and volunteer work. The rest of my time is spent managing the household, helping my son with his schoolwork, and taking care of our little garden. It's not always easy to track the hours because there's so much that goes into being a homemaker—cooking, cleaning, laundry, errands, and just being there for my son. But when I do focus on my business or volunteer work, I try to be as intentional as possible. I usually set aside specific times in the afternoons or evenings when my son is occupied with homework or activities. It's not about the number of hours, though—it's about the quality of what I do and how it contributes to my life and the lives of the people I care about.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Leticia Daniels: I didn't have more than one job or business in the traditional sense, but I did juggle a few different roles that kept me busy throughout the week. My online store was my main side hustle, and I often worked on it in the afternoons or evenings when my son was occupied. I also volunteered at the community center a couple of times a month, which added a few more hours to my week. On top of that, I was always managing the household, helping my son with his schoolwork, and tending to our garden. It wasn't always easy to keep up with everything, but I found a rhythm that worked for us. I think what made it manageable was that I didn't try to do everything at once—I focused on what was most important in the moment. It wasn't about the number of hours I worked, but about the balance I found in the different parts of my life. I'm still learning how to manage that balance, but I've come to appreciate the way my days are structured, even if it's not the same as someone with a traditional 9-to-5 job.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much I've grown in understanding my own emotional well-being and the importance of financial stability. It reminded me of the journey I've taken in learning to manage stress, set boundaries, and prioritize my mental health. I used to feel guilty for taking time for myself, but now I see it as necessary for being the best version of myself for my son and for my own peace of mind. It also made me think about how I manage our household budget and the small but meaningful ways I save and plan for the future. It's not always easy, but I've come to appreciate the balance I've found in my life, and I'm grateful for the progress I've made in both my emotional and financial well-being.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Leticia Daniels: In total, our household made around $1,800 in the past month, mostly from my online store and a small part-time gig I took on at the local library helping with inventory. It's not a lot, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and some of the things we enjoy, like our weekly trips to the park or the occasional family dinner out. I've learned to be really careful with every dollar, and I try to stretch things as much as I can. It's not always easy, but I've come to appreciate the value of what we have and the life we've built together. I also have a small side income from selling some of the herbs and vegetables we grow in our garden, which helps a little too. It's not about making a fortune, but about making sure we're taken care of and that my son has the opportunities he deserves.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Leticia Daniels: I don't have a traditional workplace in the way most people do, but if I had to describe it, I'd say my workplace is my home, my online store, and the community center where I volunteer. I've been running my online store for about five years now, and while it's not a 9-to-5 job, it has its own kind of structure and rhythm. The benefits of this kind of work are different from what you might find in a corporate job. For one, I have the flexibility to set my own hours, which is something I really value, especially as a mother. I can work when my son is occupied, and I can take breaks when I need to. That said, there are no health benefits or paid time off in the traditional sense, which is something I've had to be mindful of. I've had to build my own safety net through savings and a strong support system. I also don't get sick days or vacation time, so I have to plan my rest and recovery carefully. But I think the biggest benefit is the sense of purpose and control I have over my work. I get to create something with my own hands, connect with people who appreciate what I make, and contribute to my community in ways that matter to me. It's not perfect, but it's mine, and I'm learning to be grateful for that.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Leticia Daniels: I don't have a manager or coworkers in the traditional sense, but I do have a kind of community around my work—both online and in person. With my online store, I interact with customers who leave reviews, ask questions, and sometimes even share their own stories about how they use my products. It's a different kind of relationship, but it feels meaningful because it's built on trust and connection. When I volunteer at the community center, I work with other volunteers and staff who are all passionate about helping kids. We don't have a formal hierarchy, but there's a real sense of teamwork and mutual support. I think the relationships I've built are more personal and authentic than what I've seen in traditional workplaces. I don't have a boss who tells me what to do, but I do have people who encourage me, challenge me, and remind me why I started this journey in the first place. That kind of support, even if it's not structured like a corporate job, is something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Leticia Daniels: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which is one of the things I appreciate most about it. Unlike a traditional job with set hours, I can work when it fits best with my son's schedule and my own energy levels. Most days, I focus on my online store in the afternoons or evenings, especially when he's doing homework or involved in activities. On other days, I might spend more time volunteering at the community center or tending to the garden. That said, there are times when things get busier—like when I'm preparing for a new product launch or helping with a big event at the center—and those days can feel a bit less predictable. But overall, I like the freedom to shape my days around what matters most. It's not always easy to balance everything, but I've learned to go with the flow and make the most of the time I have.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Leticia Daniels: Overall, I feel pretty content with my financial situation, even if it's not what I originally imagined. I know we don't have a lot, but we have what we need, and sometimes more than that. I've learned to be really mindful of every dollar, and I take pride in knowing that I'm providing for my son in the best way I can. It's not about having the biggest house or the fanciest things—it's about stability, security, and being able to say yes to the things that matter most, like a family dinner, a weekend trip to the park, or even just a quiet evening with a book. I've also come to appreciate the little ways I can stretch our budget, like growing our own food or making our own cleaning supplies. It's not always easy, and there are days when I feel the weight of it all, but I've learned that financial security isn't just about numbers—it's about peace of mind, knowing that I'm doing the best I can for my son and for myself. I'm still learning, still growing, and I'm grateful for every step of the way.

Going through the interview questions about my financial situation and work habits has made me reflect on how much I've grown in learning to manage my household and find balance in my life. It reminded me of the challenges of fluctuating bills, the importance of saving even small amounts, and how my work—whether it's running my online store, volunteering, or being a homemaker—has shaped the life I have today. I used to feel uncertain about my financial stability, but now I see that it's not about having a lot, but about being intentional with what I have and making it work for my son and me. It's also made me appreciate the flexibility of my work schedule, even if it's not traditional, and how it allows me to be present for the things that matter most. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the life I've built.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Leticia Daniels: Yes, both my mom and dad worked while I was growing up, though their roles were a bit different. My dad was a teacher, and he worked full-time at a local high school for over 20 years. He always made sure to be there for us, even if it meant staying late after school or coming home late on some nights. My mom, on the other hand, had an associate's degree and worked part-time for a while, but she eventually chose to stay home with me and my brother for a few years. She worked as a receptionist at a small office, but she left that job when I was around six to focus on our family. Looking back, I think my parents both made sacrifices to give me and my brother a good life. They didn't have a lot of money, but they always made sure we had everything we needed—school supplies, books, and even the occasional treat. I remember my dad bringing home extra work sometimes, and my mom would stay up late to help him grade papers or prepare lessons. It wasn't easy, but they never made us feel like we were missing out. I think that's one of the reasons I always wanted to do well in school and make something of myself. I wanted to make sure I never had to worry about things like that, and I wanted to give my son the same kind of stability and support that my parents gave me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Leticia Daniels: My dad was a high school teacher, and his most important activities were planning lessons, grading papers, and being there for his students. He had a real passion for education, and he always made sure his students felt seen and supported. I remember him staying after school to help kids who were struggling, and he even started a tutoring program for students who needed extra help. He was strict when he needed to be, but he had a way of making you feel like he believed in you, even when you didn't believe in yourself. My mom, on the other hand, worked as a receptionist at a small office, and her duties were more about managing phone calls, scheduling appointments, and keeping the office running smoothly. She was very organized and had a great sense of humor, which made the office a more pleasant place to be. Even though she left her job to stay home with us for a while, she always said she was proud of the work she did, and I think that's why I learned to value hard work so much. Both of them had different kinds of jobs, but they both gave their all, and that's something I carry with me every day.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Leticia Daniels: My dad worked for the Charlotte Public Schools system, teaching high school English and social studies. It was a pretty traditional school setting, with a lot of students from the neighborhood we lived in. He was known for being fair but also very passionate about his subjects. He would often bring real-world examples into his lessons, making history and literature feel relevant and exciting. My mom worked for a small local law firm as a receptionist. It wasn't a big company, but it was a family-owned business, and she was one of the first people they hired. She was the one who greeted clients, scheduled appointments, and handled all the day-to-day office tasks. I remember her telling me that she loved the people she worked with and the sense of community in that office. Even though their jobs were different, both of them had a strong work ethic and always made sure they gave their best, even on the hardest days. I think that's one of the reasons I grew up valuing hard work and dedication so much—it was something they both embodied in their own ways.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Leticia Daniels: A few years from now, I hope to still be here, in this neighborhood, with my son growing up in the same place I did. I hope he's found his passion and is pursuing it with the same curiosity and determination that he has now. I also hope that I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding joy in the little things—like the way the sun hits the garden in the morning or the sound of his laughter when he's excited about something new. I don't know if I'll ever go back to school full-time or if I'll expand my online store, but I hope I'm still doing something that makes me feel purposeful and connected to the world around me. I hope I'm still surrounded by the people I love, and that I'm still able to be present for my son, for my family, and for the life we've built together. I think the future is less about where I end up and more about how I get there—with grace, with gratitude, and with the understanding that life is meant to be lived, not just survived.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Leticia Daniels: What I value the most in my life is the people I love—the relationships I've built with my son, my family, and the friends who have stood by me through thick and thin. I value the sense of home I've created here, in this neighborhood, with the same trees and familiar faces that have been part of my life for so long. I value the small moments that bring me joy, like watching my son explore the world with curiosity, or the quiet mornings when I can sit with a book and a cup of coffee, just being present. I also value the lessons I've learned along the way—about resilience, about forgiveness, about finding purpose in the everyday. Life hasn't always gone as planned, but I've come to see that the things that matter most aren't the ones you can buy or achieve. They're the ones you build, one day at a time, with love and intention.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my life has evolved in terms of my financial situation and the nature of my work. It reminded me of the challenges of managing a household on a limited income, the importance of saving even small amounts, and how my work—whether it's running my online store, volunteering, or being a homemaker—has shaped the life I have today. I used to feel uncertain about my financial stability, but now I see that it's not about having a lot, but about being intentional with what I have and making it work for my son and me. It's also made me appreciate the flexibility of my work schedule, even if it's not traditional, and how it allows me to be present for the things that matter most. I'm still learning, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the life I've built.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and self-discovery. It reminded me of how much I've grown over the years, not just in the big moments, but in the small, everyday choices that have shaped who I am today. I thought about my childhood in Charlotte, the crossroads I faced after college, the decision to raise my son alone, and the path I've taken as a homemaker, small business owner, and community volunteer. I realized how much my family, friends, and neighborhood have been constants in my life, providing support, stability, and a sense of belonging. I also reflected on my health, my financial situation, and the challenges I've faced along the way, and how they've taught me the importance of self-care, resilience, and gratitude. This interview has helped me see my life not just as a series of events, but as a story of growth, learning, and finding peace in the life I've built—with the people I love and the community that has always been there for me.
